article.title: Equilibrium gels of limited valence colloids

multiple_choice_question.text: Which of the following statements correctly describes the schematic phase diagram of limited valence particles?
choices: Equilibrium gels can be formed when particles interact via standard (core repulsion plus attraction) isotropic potentials.
The percolation line, where an incipient spanning cluster of bonded particles first appears, is always located at a temperature lower than the gas-liquid critical temperature.
Below the arrest line, where the relaxation time becomes comparable to the experimental time scale, the system becomes arrested, forming an equilibrium gel.
The gas-liquid phase separation in limited valence particles occupies a larger region of densities compared to the corresponding isotropic case.

multiple_choice_question.text: Which of the following model systems utilizes the unique properties of DNA to control particle valence and bonding interactions?
The figure shows an all-DNA gel formed by DNA tetramers. What is the key structural feature of these tetramers that enables the formation of the gel network?
choices: The central flexible core of unpaired bases.
The presence of four identical DNA strands in each tetramer.
The self-complementary six-bases sequence located at the end of each arm.
The specific sequence of bases in the DNA strands forming the double helix arms.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the increasing plateau height and relaxation time observed in the density auto-correlation function (F(q,t)) of trivalent DNA nanostars indicate as the temperature decreases?
choices: Phase separation of the DNA nanostars
Progressive growth and arrest of the gel network
